df-psgn
blocks.content: Define a function which takes the value ` 1 ` for even permutations and ` -u 1 ` for odd. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 28-Aug-2015.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-psgn(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cpsgn, cmpt(s0, universe, cmpt(s1, crab(s2, cfv(cbs, cfv(csymg, cv(s0))), wcel(cdm(cdif(cv(s2), cid)), cfn)), cio(s3, wrex(s4, cword(crn(cfv(cpmtr, cv(s0)))), wa(wceq(cv(s1), co(cfv(csymg, cv(s0)), cgsu, cv(s4))), wceq(cv(s3), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cv(s4))))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-psgn(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ pmSgn =(s0 ‚àà ùïå ‚Ü¶(s1 ‚àà { s2 ‚àà(Base `(SymGrp ` s0))| dom((s2 \ =))‚àà Fin } ‚Ü¶ iota(s3, ‚àÉ(s4 ‚àà Word(ran((pmTrsp ` s0))),(s1 =((SymGrp ` s0)[gsum]s4)‚àß s3 =(-u(1)[^](# ` s4)))))))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
}

blocks.name: df-evpm

blocks.name: psgnunilem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ psgnuni . Given two consequtive transpositions in a representation of a permutation, either they are equal and therefore equivalent to the identity, or they are not and it is possible to commute them such that a chosen point in the left transposition is preserved in the right. By repeating this process, a point can be removed from a representation of the identity. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 22-Aug-2015.)

blocks.name: psgnunilem5
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ psgnuni . It is impossible to shift a transposition off the end because if the active transposition is at the right end, it is the only transposition moving ` A ` in contradiction to this being a representation of the identity. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 25-Aug-2015.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 28-Feb-2016.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Oct-2022.)

blocks.name: psgnunilem4
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ psgnuni . An odd-length representation of the identity is impossible, as it could be repeatedly shortened to a length of 1, but a length 1 permutation must be a transposition. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 25-Aug-2015.)

blocks.name: psgnuni
blocks.content: If the same permutation can be written in more than one way as a product of transpositions, the parity of those products must agree; otherwise the product of one with the inverse of the other would be an odd representation of the identity. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 27-Aug-2015.)
blocks.origin:

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, c5))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cword(c4)))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cword(c4)))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(co(c2, cgsu, c0), co(c2, cgsu, c1)))

} = {
  fnmpti(hs0, c0, c1, cio(hs2, wrex(hs1, cword(crn(cfv(cpmtr, c3))), wa(wceq(cv(hs0), co(c2, cgsu, cv(hs1))), wceq(cv(hs2), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cv(hs1))))))))
  iotaex(hs2, wrex(hs1, cword(crn(cfv(cpmtr, c3))), wa(wceq(cv(hs0), co(c2, cgsu, cv(hs1))), wceq(cv(hs2), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cv(hs1)))))))
  psgnfval(hs0, hs2, hs1, s0, c0, c1, crn(cfv(cpmtr, c3)), c2, c3, c4)
  eqid(crn(cfv(cpmtr, c3)))
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs2.s(hs1)
  diff.hs2.s(s0)
  diff.hs1.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.c(c3)

}

thm psgnpmtr(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(cfv(c2, c0), cneg(nat1)))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(csymg, c4))
  -| wceq(c1, crn(cfv(cpmtr, c4)))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cpsgn, c4))
} = {
  eqtr3d(cfv(c2, c0), cneg(nat1), cfv(c2, co(c3, cgsu, cs1(c0))), wcel(c0, c1))
  fveq2d(c2, co(c3, cgsu, cs1(c0)), c0, wcel(c0, c1))
  syl(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(co(c3, cgsu, cs1(c0)), c0), wcel(c0, cfv(cbs, c3)))
  gsumws1(c0, cfv(cbs, c3), c3)
  syl6eq(cfv(c2, co(c3, cgsu, cs1(c0))), cneg(nat1), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cs1(c0))), wcel(c0, c1))
  syl2anc(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(cfv(c2, co(c3, cgsu, cs1(c0))), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cs1(c0)))), wcel(c4, universe), wcel(cs1(c0), cword(c1)))
  syl(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c4, universe), wcel(c0, cfv(cbs, c3)))
  sseli(c0, c1, cfv(cbs, c3))
  symgtrf(c1, cfv(cbs, c3), c4, c3)
  elbasfv(c0, cfv(cbs, c3), c4, c3, csymg)
  eqid(cfv(cbs, c3))
  s1cl(c0, c1)
  psgnvalii(c4, universe, cs1(c0), c1, c2, c3)
  eqtri(co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cs1(c0))), cneg(nat1), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, nat1))
  oveq2i(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, cs1(c0)), nat1)
  s1len(c0)
  ax-mp(wceq(co(cneg(nat1), cexp, nat1), cneg(nat1)), wcel(cneg(nat1), cc))
  neg1cn()

}

blocks.content: A permutation of a finite set has exactly one parity. (Contributed by AV, 13-Jan-2019.)

thm psgnfieu(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {

  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c4))
  -| wceq(c3, crn(cfv(cpmtr, c0)))

  -| diffsc(s0, c4)

  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c4)

  simpr(wcel(c0, cfn), wcel(c1, c2))
